newsitem.title: BURMA: Burma pro-govt group stages new rally against U.S..
newsitem.headline: Burma pro-govt group stages new rally against U.S..

text.p: More than 20,000 people from a Burmese group backed by the government staged a rally in Karen State this week and attacked the United States for interfering in the country's internal affairs.

Official newspapers and state-run television on Thursday showed pictures of the rally, which took place on Monday and was attended by about 20,570 members of the Union Solidarity and Development Association.
Speakers at the rally urged the crowd to oppose Washington for imposing sanctions on Burma's military government.

"I would like to call on the rally to oppose the so-called world police, the American government, which is interfering in our internal affairs to jeopardise national interests and to dominate our country," said Kyaw Htay, secretary of the Karen State USDA.
He also urged people to crush "traitors" like opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi who was a strong proponent of sanctions.

This is the third mass rally held by the association since April 22 when the United States banned all new American investment in Burma. The sanctions were meant as a condemnation of Rangoon's poor human rights record, and its repression of Suu Kyi's democracy movement.
At least 10 more rallies were expected to take place in large cities across the country, analysts said.

Similar rallies have been staged over the past few years to denounce Suu Kyi and her National League for Democracy party. Speakers often urge people to "crush" or "annihilate" anyone who opposes the government or threatens to destabilise it.
Diplomats call the rallies staged, while residents say they are often forced by military officials or police to attend.
